awd_titl_txt: Using Networks to Scale Improvement of STEM Undergraduate Education: A Comparative Study of Network Goals, Processes, and Strategies to Advance Organizational Change
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will advance knowledge of organization-focused change networks as a potentially powerful lever for advancing improvements in undergraduate STEM education. This four-year project will examine how organization-focused change networks support and advance STEM undergraduate educational improvement. Based on a theory of change that networks can scale advances in STEM education, this research builds on and integrates knowledge from 3 different knowledge bases: organizational change, networks, and STEM education. Six networks that connect organizations or that connect institutional leaders working directly with organizational units or departments will be studied: the Advanced Technological Education Network; the Bay View Alliance; the Center for the Integration of Research, Teaching, and Learning; the Network of STEM Education Centers; the Partnership for Undergraduate Life Sciences Education; and the Reinvention Center. The project will use cross-case analysis to identify lessons concerning effective strategies and processes for optimal network functioning and impact. During year 3, teams from each network will be convened in a knowledge exchange symposium to discuss emerging findings, exchange perspectives on network development, functioning, and impact, and identify important implications and lessons for other networks.

The project will use rigorous qualitative methods, including document analysis, interviews, and site visits, to examine three aspects of each network. The first is the network's design, including its purpose and problem addressed, and the theory of change guiding its work, membership, and structures. The second concerns the network's lifecycle and processes, including stages of network development, strategies used to advance goals related to STEM undergraduate education, issues and challenges, and how those issues are handled. The third aspect is the network's outcomes, impact, and scale, including: metrics and processes used to provide feedback on progress, what outcomes and impacts are assessed to determine progress toward network goals, and strategies used to extend the reach and scale of the network.

por.por_cntn:
A growing number of networks are forming with the purpose of improving undergraduate STEM teaching and learning. The promise of such networks is great, yet relatively little is known about the key features, processes, outcomes, and impacts of networks that aspire to improve undergraduate STEM education. In particular, while networks comprised of individuals have been studied, little research has focused on Organizational Change Networks (OCNs), defined as networks that connect higher education organizations to imagine and advance improvement agendas. Using rigorous and proven qualitative methods, this project has studied the features, processes, outcomes, and impacts of a set of OCNs, and, through cross-case analysis, has identified and disseminated key lessons learned about such networks that may aid future network leaders. While the project has focused specifically on understanding more about effective ways in which OCNs can nurture, support, and advance reform in STEM undergraduate education, we believe the lessons learned are relevant to a range of networks advancing substantial change goals in higher education.

The networks studied include: the Advanced Technological Education Network (ATE); the Bay View Alliance (BVA); the Center for the Integration of Research, Teaching, and Learning (CIRTL); the Network of STEM Education Centers (NSEC); the PULSE Fellows Network (PULSE); and the Reinvention Collaborative (recently renamed the Association for Undergraduate Education at Research Universities—UERU). The specific questions addressed were: (1) How do Organizational Change Networks advance STEM undergraduate reform? (2) What does the research suggest about lessons and promising practices? Qualitative methods, including participant observation, interviews, focus groups, and document analysis, were used to conduct the study.

Noteworthy outcomes of this project have included: greater definitional clarity about OCNs; a conceptual framework for Understanding OCNs; and guidance for current and potential network leaders, those interested in organizational practices, and researchers interested in understanding networks.

  • Development of a Definition of OCNs: Through this project, we have refined the definition of Organizational Change Networks (OCNs) as networks that connect higher education institutions to work together in envisioning and advancing improvement agendas. These networks experience dynamics in ways distinct from networks comprised of individual members. 
  • Development of a Conceptual Framework for Understanding Organizational Change Networks (OCNs). The research-based framework that resulted from this study elucidates how OCNs interact with their environments, evolve over time through several stages (i.e., Formation, Development and Growth, Maturity, and Transformation), and address recurring challenges. The Framework provides sets of questions useful for consideration at various stages of a network’s development. It aids network leaders in identifying where to direct their attention and efforts within the dynamic context in which networks are situated, and also provides a guide for scholars seeking to focus on specific aspects of network development and functioning.
  • Contributions to Leadership, Practice, and Scholarship: Papers and presentations sharing project results, and a Knowledge Exchange convening more than 40 higher education leaders, enabled a range of stakeholders to benefit from the project results. These dissemination initiatives provided ideas and practical tools for network leaders and for higher education leaders wanting to support networks as levers for change, as well as a conceptual framework for researchers interested in delving further into questions about the purposes, development, nature, functioning, and impact of networks as influential change levers in higher education.

Overall, the project has expanded and deepened knowledge of how Organizational Change Networks develop, function, and make an impact in higher education, especially in improving STEM education. Network leaders have reported excitement at finding the lessons and framework resulting from this project have given them new and useful perspectives about their own networks, and have helped them anticipate issues to consider. Other higher education leaders have found the findings contribute to their understanding of the potential of OCNs as levers for change. Researchers have received this work as an important contribution to deeper understanding of networks and organizational change processes in higher education. In addition to the products of the project disseminated to date, we anticipate completing a Handbook for Network Leaders that will highlight useful lessons about network initiation, development, and growth. We also know from personal communication with various network leaders that our findings are being used to guide discussions and efforts to advance impact and effectiveness within OCNs (both in OCNs within our study group and others who have learned about the work).
